comments.commentBody: The vast majority of humanities majors do not have any solid background in the sciences. In fact most of them are scientifically illiterate.

I'm a physician who knew those kids who studied non-traditional STEM majors in college but ended up going to med school. I can testify that the best doctors, either STEM or liberal arts, have a broad exposure in college and life. It has NOTHING to do with your major in college. Heck I got my A's in liberal arts classes to raise my GPA in college b/c those hard-core sciences were so tough!

But I knew plenty of liberal arts majors without jobs. So what happened to those kids who couldn't get into med school after those 4 years? Your self-selection bias and self-preservation can't explain why students are getting smarter about spending 200k on a liberal arts college degree. We obviously need more STEM majors, otherwise why we are giving away too many foreign worker visas to foreign computer programers while our liberal arts major children are slaving away at low-paying "internships" and Starbucks after college? That's so wrong! Let's hire Americans to do American jobs.

I say if you want to increase American exposure to liberal arts, make students take more required liberal arts classes to graduate. But to tell them to become philosophy majors without a prospect for jobs is both cruel and a burden to our society who needs more engineers and scientists.
I find it funny that it's usually those already comfortably employed that call for the 'well-rounded intellectual college system. I wonder what the unemployed well rounded graduate thinks...

My wife the music history (and bio)  major, now a physician who trains residents, is a better doctor and teacher because of her experience in the humanities.  She often says that she wishes that more of the young physicians she encounters had a broader undergraduate base.  As someone who teaches college, I find that my best students are those who embrace the idea of well-rounded intellectual development and who take a good mix of humanities, physical and social science courses.  I teach history, but I have a solid undergraduate background that includes a good amount of biology, chemistry, art history and psychology courses, among other things.  I think that I'm a better teacher, parent and community member as a result.  Education is not an either science or humanities thing.  Unfortunately, we are at risk of losing a generation of kids to the idea that college should be some kind of pragmatic, narrowly focused career preparation.  College should help to develop well-rounded, intelligent citizens to maintain a flourishing society.  We also are at risk of losing the institutional capacity to educate such citizens as we gut the programs that no longer "sell" well.

David, Fortunately for us Boston fans, the Sox play better than they look.  I agree that the Sox look scruffy, but their heart and skill make up for it. Red Sox Nation, myself included, are celebrating tonight.

Out of all of the comments here, only one was neutral--and not exactly positive. Perhaps the only benefits of this conference was for students of the institute looking to make a VERY profitable career in the revolving door between Wall Street and Washington, some booked up hotel rooms, fuel for air travel (probably private), and perhaps a few working stiffs made higher tips than usual, but I'm not betting on the latter.

Speech restrictions in Singapore tend to focus on critique without basis.

For those reasons, intelligent, educated, objective people tend to like it here just fine. There are plenty of start ups with substance in Singapore, plenty trying to change the world. Our geography and proximity to NY and SFO do not any less noble our quest make. We tend not to blow our own horn too much, we'd rather keep our heads down, execute, and quietly change the world, as we are.

One example: TrakInvest.

Take a flawed law.

Throw in out of touch bureaucrats and privateer contractors chasing an easy government buck trying to implement it. And what do you get?

Idiocracy.

Paul Krugman put it best a couple of days ago in these NY Times pages, "A society committed to the notion that government is always bad will [always] have bad government."

Thanks for the self-fulfilling prophesy, Inglz.

Rita, you are right, but not for the reasons you think.  The ignorance comes from everyone calling this a health care bill, when it is really an insurance bill.  And what good is insurance if no doctors will accept it?  We are already seeing cash only clinics and specialists who are refusing medicare and medicaid patients.  But I'm sure its nothing King Obama can't fix by waving his magic wand.

skeptic,

You must have missed the article describing the army of "public service" political attack groups funded by the Koch Brothers, to the tune of 250 million dollars.

Yes, it is a right-wing cabal. And before you tell me that Koch is a Libertarian, I'll tell you that he was one of the primary funders of the Tea Party, and the American Libertarian movement is a cover for Koch's extreme right-wing views.

You do know that that sweet old racist Ron Paul claimed to be a Libertarian but was actually in bed with the John Birch Society, don't you? That's where the Libertarian party is: it's an extremist right-wing party.
Joe....That IS  what happened, Contractors did the work.
Our web developers, competent ones working in private industry, gather real-time usage and sales statistics.  It is not rocket science.  Quit the excuses and admit the king has no clothes.

Oh so because it started under Bush, Obama had no power to stop it?  Instead, the "smartest guy in the room" expanded it.  I can't the image the mental gymnastics it takes to let Obama off the hook for his lies and incompetence.
A single term won't work.  A president elected without any chance for re-election would automatically become a lame duck on election night.

I suggest Dr. Gordon Neufeld, a Canadian psychologist who has recognized and the crucial link between a parent's relationship to their child and the child's healthy development. He has articulated what many parents know in their hearts, but cannot explain. His understanding of child development takes the focus away from a short term view of 'fixing' a child's 'bad' behaviour to gaining insight into a child's experience and the meaning of a child's behaviour. Few of us understand what is most important to a child, but Neufeld explains it beautifully. On his website (neufeldinstitute.com) are many video courses that can be taken online and are understandable to parents and others involved with children. If you want to understand what is behind the success reported in this article, then look into Neufeld's work. No quick fix. He doesn't tell parents what to do, but helps them to see their children with new eyes. (As a bonus, it will help you understand all your relationships!)

He also has a book, co-authored by Gabor Mate, called Hold On To Your Kids.
Powerful piece.  Thank you.

I keep having to write this: Carter was far from perfect, but the idea that he was a failed president (other than politically) is residue from the nonsensical Reagan years with the supine media adulation that accompanied him. To the media and the proto-Teanuts that followed Reagan, he was not a doddering bad actor but a god and therefore the foe he vanquished had to be bad. You can do the blame game for the Iran hostage situation if you want, but somehow Bush got re-elected after 9/11 and the grossly questionable and perverted military/security measures that he initiated. Not a god, but a good honest man (if not the greatest politician, and certainly an independent moderate at the time - which was probably one of his major weaknesses in his own party), Carter was a political scapegoat for everyone, period.

Forget Iran. Just one thing alone makes Carter stand out as a major foreign policy leader of our nation in the second half of the 20th century : the Panama Canal Treaty. This was one of the things that the frothing rightists of the time initially hated most (they soon forgot about it because it turned out really well).

If our image in the world now has some tarnish, think what that little imperialistic symbol would mean if it were still here. Carter forced the treaty through Congress against the ravings of people like Reagan whose most principled response was "We bought, we paid for it, it's ours". Yippee kaiyay, pardner! Thank goodness for Carter on that.

Although I am no fan of George W. Bush as a President, the former President and Laura Bush are aggressively promoting global health issues, especially the fight against HIV, AIDS and cervical cancer, through the Red Ribbon Pink Ribbon Program at the George W. Bush Institute. The major focus is women's health care in Africa. Indeed, it's a tall order to stand up to the legacy of Jimmy Carter's humanitarian activities, but every step, any step, no matter how small, toward better global health for all is important and welcome. You might want to visit the web site: http://www.bushcenter.org/global-health/pink-ribbon-red-ribbon .

To Q2-- Forget Iran???

It's almost as though the Hostage Crisis never happened.

Jimmy Carter had the best second term of recent presidents, because he lost.  He had a second act instead, doing some honorable charity work, such as the effort to eradicate the dreadful Guinea Worm parasite.  At least that is better than G. W. Bush, who sits at home painting pictures of his feet.
16%? Sounds like a good time to quit the crack of charging things you don't really need.

This is the largest ripoff of the poor by the rich in American history. The fed has ground the working classes savings into dust. The banks are paying O.20% in interest and charging 16 % on credit cards. It is time to throw the money changers out of our government.

I'd like to know what your reasoning is based on other than emotions.

If the Fed had not been buying securities and mortgages most economists would say things would only have gotten worse than they have.

Yet, if the spirit of your point is that there would have been better ways of stimulating the economy, then most economists would agree with you. Even the Fed says that the sharp decrease in federal spending (yes, federal spending has gone down a lot) is a major factor in weakness of the economy.
Hey let's not forget the trillions we dump overseas on military adventures and propping up dictators.  No return on that.

Growth will continue to stumble as long as corporate investment goes abroad rather than here.  Our foreign trade deficits continue to burgeon and pose much greater "leakage" than taxes.  We need a concerted proactive effort from our corporations to bring the jobs back that they shipped overseas to cheaper slave markets where they neglect to enforce basic common decency for work and work conditions.

Welcome indeed.
I saw the light in 1984 when I realized that Reagan/Bush were bankrupting the country.
I changed my registration to Democrat and have never looked back.
It is all about social and economic justice and the Common Good.
How can we tell if that's the thing that sickened us?

Actually, quite a few people get sick. A quick web search turned up this story from England:

"Food Poisoning Reported From Street Spice Food Festival" http://tyneandwear.sky.com/news/article/58778/dozens-of-food-poisoning-c...

Everyone who's gotten sick from contaminated imported spices, raise your hand.... no one?  That's what I thought. Sometimes (trace) dirt sounds more disgusting than it is. Sure, making it cleaner would be good, but in the meantime, carry on.
I agree with Jonathan! I guess the far right doesn't eat food flavored with spices, so it's OK to poison the rest of us in the name of free enterprise.

No one thinks that you can get bug parts out 100%, but it is way unacceptable to just roll over and accept whole bugs in our food!

And you are A-OK with rat feces??? I don't even know what to say to that.

Now everyone knows that spices food..frozen and canned all have the same thing...it's monitored but it's impossible to get them 100% free of body parts and bugs...I started using whole pepper in a pepper mill long ago because of the amount of rat feces..started buying only fresh or frozen for that reason...so this doesn't alarm me that much...it's repulsive..but it goes on here as well..
The report says spices. HERBS like rosemary are more likely to be domestic & garlic needs to be peeled & prepared to use so it's probably safe.

With all due respect, this is a rather mean-spirited way of looking at things. We're still one nation. Citizens should have access to affordable health insurance no matter how they voted. Don't castigate, educate.
